Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: The shrill site alarm jolts me from my focus, and I drop my tools, heart pounding. As a construction laborer, I know the drill: when the alarm sounds, you don’t hesitate. You leave everything and head straight to the muster point, no questions asked. The foreman’s voice echoes in my head—protocols are strict for a reason, and the team depends on everyone following them. But as I join the line of workers shuffling toward the exit, my mind drifts to the envelope of tax documents sitting on my kitchen table, all sorted and ready, and the flyer I saw this morning about the free vaccine clinic at the community center this weekend. As a citizen, I feel the weight of responsibility to do my part—paying taxes on time, staying healthy, and helping others do the same. The demands of both roles press in on me, each urgent in its own way. I feel torn, caught between the immediate safety of my coworkers and the broader duty I owe to my community. My chest tightens as I wrestle with which expectation should come first.
